page.title: 10BLACKO METHODIST CHAPEL
page.content: In{1836}a barn at{BLACKO}was used for services, it was also used as a Sunday School. In{1849}the chapel was campaigned for by a group of men who had been expelled from the{WESLEYAN {CONFERENCE.}The chapel was finally built on land bought in{1868}and is a member of the{INDEPENDENT METHODIST {CONNEXION}which has an evangelical approach and an unpaid ministry. Relations with the village have always been mutually supportive and when the roof fell in about thirty years ago, the villagers helped with money and with some of the rebuilding. Weekly Congregations are now in the low twenties although many villagers attend social functions. The Chapel Sunday School provides a home for the{ {YOUTH CLUB,}Whist Drives, a Mother and Baby Group and other meetings.
